title: Veterans Aging Cohort Study (VACS) 1.0 Index
description: Estimates 5-year all-cause mortality risk in patients with HIV and/or HCV by integrating HIV-specific biomarkers (CD4 count, HIV-1 RNA) with general health indicators (hemoglobin, liver function, kidney function, and hepatitis C co-infection).

parameters.name: fib4_index
parameters.description: FIB-4 Index for liver fibrosis assessment (calculated using age, ALT, AST, and platelet count)

result.name: vacs_score
result.description: VACS 1.0 Index score with 5-year mortality risk estimate

ranges.interpretation: VACS Index score indicates low 5-year mortality risk. Continue regular HIV care and monitoring. Focus on HIV suppression, adherence to antiretroviral therapy, and routine comorbidity screening.

VACS Index score indicates moderate 5-year mortality risk. Enhanced monitoring recommended. Address modifiable risk factors including liver disease, kidney function, and anemia. Consider more frequent clinical evaluations.

VACS Index score indicates high 5-year mortality risk. Intensive management recommended. Prioritize treatment of liver disease, kidney dysfunction, and severe anemia. Consider specialist referrals and more aggressive interventions.

VACS Index score indicates very high 5-year mortality risk. Urgent comprehensive management required. Immediate attention to life-threatening comorbidities. Consider palliative care discussions alongside aggressive treatment.

references: Justice AC, McGinnis KA, Skanderson M, et al. Towards a combined prognostic index for survival in HIV infection: the role of 'non-HIV' biomarkers. HIV Med. 2010;11(2):143-151.
Tate JP, Justice AC, Hughes MD, et al. An internationally generalizable risk index for mortality prediction in HIV-infected adults. AIDS. 2013;27(4):563-572.
Justice AC, Dombrowski E, Conigliaro J, et al. Veterans Aging Cohort Study (VACS): Overview and description. Med Care. 2006;44(8 Suppl 2):S13-24.
notes: The VACS 1.0 Index has been validated in diverse HIV+ populations including both veterans and non-veterans.
Higher scores indicate increased 5-year all-cause mortality risk.
The index integrates both HIV-specific markers and general health biomarkers for comprehensive risk assessment.
FIB-4 Index calculation: (Age × AST) / (Platelet count × √ALT). Values >3.25 suggest advanced liver fibrosis.
This tool is most accurate in patients with at least 1 year of antiretroviral therapy exposure.
The VACS Index has shown better discrimination than HIV markers alone (C-statistic 0.77 vs 0.74).
